page.title: 15Wilf Bottomley (stone mason)
page.content: {Mr Bottomley}was working on the extension of the shop at the museum. Although he is now retired,he was shaping stone sills and lintels for the windows.Two young men were roofing the extension,under his eye,with grey slate,the local stone used for roofs.These are thinner than the flags used for floors and as he said, "There's nothing like stone for building". He was proud that the new building was in keeping with the traditional character of the town.A new housing estate built in Yorkshire stone had won an architectural award recently. He started work in a woollen mill at 14 but soon became apprenticed to a stone mason.He has worked on churches and other buildings all over the area and{"makes nowt"}of modern materials which don't last two minutes.
